comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I have been trying to puzzle this one out for months - now successful ! Photo taken from on top of a Gas Holder (hence the great height) at the corner of Pitt Street and what was then Gipps St West and Garden Road, looking SE across the Old Cemeteries towards Surry Hills. The whole area was resumed and flattened to make Central Station in the early 1900s. Eddy Avenue roughly follows Garden Road. Easier to understand when looking at this interactive 1895 map of Sydney, which shows the tram route and depot - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=0... . The picture could be as early as 1880 - the original steam tram was built between Sydney Terminus and Circular Quay to take people to the Exhibition at the Garden Palace from 1879.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Looking at the photograph with your well researched notes I can see where Eddy Ave would be and where Central Station now is situated.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There's just one problem - the 1870 Exhibition Building in Alfred Park ( www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3793508243/ ) should be visible in the distance. I cannot see it at this resolution; maybe it is just lost in the overexposure?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Hi beachcomberaustralia, I have replaced this image with a larger version, if that helps you.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Thanks State Records NSW, the large size is brilliant.  I found the Exhibition Building (see note).  What looks like a series of bridges underneath, is <del>possibly a railway shed under construction</del> an avenue of trees around Prince Alfred Park.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: Beachcomberaustralia, thanks for the map.....such a different world back then!

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: The Good Samaritan Female Refuge, the stone building in the foreground, is where the Central Station clocktower stands today.

comment._content:

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Might have to rethink the c.1880 date of this photo,  due to the Anthony Hordern warehouse parapet bottom right which appears in the sequence of photos of the building of Central Station (see link on the note). 

Perhaps this is a 'before' photo of Central Station c.1900 - the demolition work seems to have started behind the Good Samaritan Female Refuge, and the Tramway Depot is in a bad state of repair
